journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: A novel small-world algorithm incorporating chaos optimization and its application to robot path planning

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mechatronics and Automotive Engineering, Jiangsu University of Science and Technology, China
2School of Mechanical Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, China

author-notes.corresp: Ming Xin Yuan, School of Mechatronics and Automotive Engineering, Jiangsu University of Science and Technology, Zhangjiagang, China. Email: mxyuan78@gmail.com

abstract.p: By making use of the characteristics of ergodicity, randomicity and regularity of chaotic variables and information entropy, a novel chaotic small-world algorithm is presented to improve the optimization performance of the simple small-world algorithm. Compared with the corresponding simple small-world algorithm and the modified genetic algorithm approach, the optimization results of selected complex functions indicate that the proposed chaotic small-world algorithm is characterized by a strong search capability and a quick convergence speed. A study of parameter performance of the chaotic small-world algorithm aids in further improvement of its optimization capability. Additionally, the chaotic small-world algorithm is applied to mobile robot path planning, and the global path is optimized by the chaotic small-world algorithm based on a MAKLINK graph. Finally, experimental results verify the validity of the chaotic small-world algorithm for robot path planning.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The hypothesis that a small chain of intermediate social acquaintances connects any two individuals in the world is known as the small-world phenomenon. To quantitatively verify this phenomenon, in 1967, American social psychologist Stanley Milgram performed an experiment that traced short paths through the social networks of the United States by forwarding letters and put forward the famous “six degrees of separation” hypothesis based on his results.1 Milgram’s experiment led to two striking discoveries: one was the existence of short paths, and the other was that people in society, with knowledge of only their own personal acquaintances, were able to quickly forward a letter to a distant target.2 The second discovery showed that people are able to effectively find shortcuts by using local information when the network presents a certain topology. In 1998, Watts and Strogatz presented a rigorous model of this phenomenon and constructed a small-world network.3 Since then, complex network theory has become a subject of great interest to researchers and has been successfully used in wireless sensor networks,4 disease propagation,5 transportation networking6 and other fields. However, little discussion regarding the small-world phenomenon is found in the field of optimization algorithms. Inspired by the mechanism of the small-world phenomenon in Milgram’s experiment, Du et al.1 presented the first new function optimization algorithm, known as the small-world algorithm (SWA) which consisted of a random long-range search operator and a local shortcut search operator. Wang et al. 7 used the simple small-world algorithm (SSWA) to find a quality of service unicast path with the Pareto optimum under the Nash equilibrium condition with both the network provider utility and the user utility achieved or approached. A large number of simulation results have shown that the optimization performance of the SSWA is better than that of genetic algorithm (GA)-based approaches in terms of factors such as the diversity, convergence and search capability. However, the SSWA emphasises the search for local shortcuts too heavily during the optimization, and it tends to become trapped in local minima once the local neighborhood ceases to be in effect. Moreover, the operational mechanism of the local shortcut search is so simple that the convergence performance and optimization capability of the SSWA are weakened to an extent. To address the observation that the SSWA is prone to trapping in local minima during optimization, Chen et al.8 provided a SWA that possessed replacing and tracking characteristics. To solve the multi-variable optimization problem, Li et al.9 presented a decimal-coded SWA for high-dimensional function optimization that avoided the problem of coding and decoding caused by an over-long binary string. The chaos optimization algorithm10 is a new kind of search method, and has strong search ability in the local search. In this paper, to further improve the search capability and search efficiency of the SSWA for simple local shortcuts search, the chaos optimization is introduced into the SSWA. In addition, to retain the population diversity of the SSWA, an evaluation criterion is constructed by integrating the individual concentration and fitness, and the individuals with high concentration are replaced.

As one of the most important tasks for autonomous mobile robot navigation, path planning refers to the search for an optimal and collision-free path from the starting point to the goal based on certain optimization criteria (e.g. minimal working cost, shortest route, etc.). At present, the conventional path planning methods include the artificial potential field (APF) method,11 fuzzy logic method,12 GAs13 and an ant colony algorithm (ACA).14 A simple model, small calculation sizes and favorable real-time operation characterize the APF method; however, it also easily becomes trapped in local minima. The fuzzy logic method overcomes the problem of trapping in local minima; however, human experience is not integrated into this method. A GA has a global search capability, but its encoding is complicated, and the search efficiency is low. The ACA is characterized by robustness and a global optimization capability; however, the search capability is limited to the divisions of a grid. In this paper, the chaotic small-world algorithm (CSWA) is introduced to optimize the global path for mobile robot path planning based on the MAKLINK graph.

sec.title: Descriptions and definitions of the SSWA
sec.p: The small-world phenomenon revealed in Milgram’s experiment is a highly effective mode of information transmission via movement through complex networks that consist of highly clustered sub-networks composed of “local acquaintances” of nodes together with a collection of random long-range shortcuts that produce short paths.2 The small-world network constructed by Watts and Strogatz is a middle network configuration that extends from a regular network to a random network and combines local clustering shortcuts with selected random long-range shortcuts: N nodes are distributed on a ring, and each node has k connections.3 First, each node connects with the nearest k nodes, and the connection of each node is adjusted randomly with probability p, but each node cannot connect with itself. Figure 1 shows the construction principle of a small-world network when N = 20 and k = 4. In this figure it is shown that the constructed small-world network reflects the characteristics of local shortcuts and random long-range shortcuts when p = 0.2.

caption.p: Construction principle of the small-world network (N=20, k=4): (a) regular (p = 0); (b) small world (p = 0.2); and (c) random (p = 1).

sec.p: Kleinberg noted that the small-world phenomenon presents an efficiency problem in the routing algorithm, where local knowledge is sufficient to find effective paths to the destination.1,2 Accordingly, in this paper, the optimization problem based on the small-world phenomenon can be described as follows: The optimization process concerns information transmission from the candidate solutions (i.e. candidate nodes) to the optimal solution (i.e. optimal node) in the search space (i.e. network), and the small-world phenomenon is considered during the search. In other words, global random search (i.e. random long-range connections) is introduced on the basis of the local search (i.e. local shortcut connections).

The search principle of the SSWA in a two-dimensional (2D) workspace is shown schematically in Figure 2. A candidate node moves to the optimal node through a random long-range search and a local search for shortcuts, and the transmitted information is the solution of the optimal model. For the function optimization, the transmitted information is the distance between the current solution and the global optimal solution.

caption.p: Search principle of the SSWA in a 2D workspace.

sec.p: Without loss of generality, the following global optimization model is considered15
where x={x1,x2,⋯,xm}, m is the dimension of x, and d={d1,d2,⋯,dm} and u={u1,u2,⋯,um} are the lower bound vector and upper bound vector of x, respectively, namely, ∀1≤i≤m, xi∈[di,ui].
To simplify the description of the CSWA, the following definitions are provided.

sec.title: Definition 1
sec.p: Let s∈S (s=a1a2⋯am) be the binary code of vector x. ∀ai, 1 ≤i≤m, its string length be li and be related to the coding precision of variable xi. ai=bi1bi2⋯bili, bij∈{0,1}, 1 ≤j≤li. The total string length of s is M=∑i=1mli.

sec.title: Definition 2
sec.p: Let σ be the coding precision of variable xi. The string length li of ai can be defined as follows
where fix(·) is the round function and returns the integer part of a number.
The decoding of ai can be defined as
where e−1(·) represents the decoding method. Let e(·) be the coding method, and thus ai = e(xi).

sec.title: Definition 3
sec.p: For ∀si∈S, the l neighbourhood set of node sj can be defined as1
where ║·║ is the Hamming distance.

sec.title: Definition 4
sec.p: For ∀si∈S, the non- l neighborhood set of si can be defined as1

sec.p: The average information entropy of the entire population is defined as

sec.title: Definition 6
sec.p: Let Aij be the similarity between individuals si and sj

sec.title: The SSWA
sec.p: The SSWA is inspired by the mechanism of the small-world phenomenon and includes a random long-range search operator Γ and a local shortcuts search operator Ψ.1
For ∀si(k)∈S(k); the main action of Г is to transmit the information from si(k) to s′i(k) with a given preset long-rang search probability pc, that is
where rand (0-1) generates a uniformly distributed random number whose values fall between zero and one.

Suppose that Ri(k)⊆ζl(s′i(k)) is the local search space of node s′i(k), and the main action of Ψ is to transmit the information from node s′i(k) to si(k+1), which is the nearest node in Ri(k) from the global optimal node of optimization model, that is
The specific operation processes of Г and Ψ of the SSWA are discussed in Du et al.1
The pseudo-code for the SSWA can be described as follows.
In the pseudo-code, s* is the optimal individual of the kth generation population, and f* is the global optimum of model f.

sec.title: Chaos optimization operator
sec.p: In the SSWA, the main operation of Ψ is to randomly search a node in ζl(si(k)). The operation method of Ψ is so simple that the local search capability of the SSWA is weakened. In addition, the initial population is randomly generated, a process which cannot guarantee an abundant mode for the initial population. To further improve the optimization capability of the SSWA, chaos optimization is introduced.

The optimization method based on chaos theory makes use of the favorable characteristics of the chaos sequence, (e.g. ergodicity, randomicity and regularity) to search for optimal solutions of the optimization model.
The logistic equation proposed by May in 1976 is a typical chaotic system and can be described as
where η is the so-called driving parameter.

Equation (12) starts with a fixed value of η, and an initial value of z0. Then z1, z2,…, zn can be obtained by running the equation recursively. Let υ be the total recursive generation. The logistic equation is commonly used as the demographic mode. Figure 3 presents a bifurcation diagraph of the logistic map. From the figure, it can be observed that the chaos system produces different behavior with the increase of η:

caption.p: Bifurcation diagraph of the logistic map.

list-item.p: if 0<η≤1, the population zt will approach zero;
if 1<η<3, the population zt will quickly approach the value 1−1/η;
if 3≤η≤4, the population zt will transit from period 2 to the chaotic region;
if η>4, the population zt will eventually leave the interval [0,1] and tend towards divergence.

sec.p: Considering that zt∈(0,1) when η=4, (namely, the variables fill the chaos space), the initial population S(0) is generated using the logistic equation. Because the initial population S(0) resides in the binary-coding space, zt should be transformed into the binary-coding space. The transformation among different spaces will be described in the following paragraphs.
To improve the weak local search capability of the SSWA, the chaotic disturbance is introduced again, and the individuals with smaller fitness values are locally searched.
The chaotic disturbance is usually formulated as

where β is a chaos variable and is achieved through the transformation of an individual in population S(k). β* is the corresponding optimal chaotic variable of the optimal individual in S(k). α is an adjustment coefficient. The chaotic disturbance is also a recursive process; let λ be the total number of iterative generations.
The transformation from s(k) to β involves two steps.

list-item.p: Step 1. ∀1≤i≤m, and the element ai(k)of s(k) is transformed into xi(k) from the binary-coding space to the variable space, namely xi(k)=e−1(ai(k)).
Step 2. ∀1≤i≤m, xi(k) is transformed into βi (βi∈β) from the variable space to the chaotic space

sec.p: Let Θ−1(·) be the inverse transformation, so xi(k)=Θ−1(βi), 1≤i≤m.
Let s*(k)=a1*(k)a2*(k)⋯am*(k) be the optimal individual of population S(k). ∀1≤i≤m, xi*(k)=e−1(ai*(k)). β*={Θ(x1*(k)),Θ(x2*(k)),⋯,Θ(xm*(k))}.

During the early search of the SWA, the individuals of population S(k) are expected to be altered dramatically to finish the rough search. Therefore, the value of α should become larger. While the search goes on, the individuals of S(k) are close to the optimal solution of the optimization model. Next, the value of α should be gradually reduced to finish the exact search. In view of these observations, the adjustment coefficient α is defined as follows
where p is a constant and p=2 in this paper. Also, k is the evolutionary generation of population S.

sec.title: Population updating operator based on information entropy
sec.p: To resolve the stagnancy of the SSWA, information entropy is introduced to calculate the individual concentration. The individuals with high concentration are replaced based on the individual concentration and the individual fitness value, which retains the population diversity. The detailed operation steps are as follows.

list-item.p: Step 1. Execute the sorting operation T on population S(k) according to the individual fitness, and generate new population S′(k)

Step 2. Calculate the individual concentration. During the population updating operation, a recursive calculation method is presented that will ensure that the individuals with a higher concentration and smaller fitness value are replaced.

sec.p: Since ∀s′i(k)∈S′(k), 1≤i≤n, the individual concentration of s′i(k) is defined as
where
and ϑ is the preset threshold value of the similarity. Aij is the individual similarity and can be obtained using equation (9).

list-item.p: Step 3. Set threshold value χ of the concentration and choose the population S″(k)={s″1(k),s″2(k),⋯,s″l(k)}⊆S′(k) with higher individual concentration. ∀s″i(k)∈S″(k), Di≥χ, 1≤i≤l.
Step 4. Replace the population S″(k) from S′(k) and generate a new population S(k+1) that can be written as

sec.p: where S∘ is the new population and is obtained using equation (12). S∘ and S″(k) have the same dimension, and S∘∩(S(k)−S′(k))=ϕ.

sec.title: Flow of the CSWA

list-item.p: Step 1. Initialize the following parameters: n, l, pc, σ,ϑ, χ, υ, λ and kmax. k← 0.
Step 2. Generate the initial population S(0) using equation (12).
Step 3. Execute the optimization of the population S(k)={s1(k),s2(k),⋯,sn(k)} based on the SWA.
3.2. Execute the random long-range search Γ with given pc: s′i(k)←Γ(si(k)), si(k)∈S(k), 1≤i≤n;
3.3. Execute the local shortcuts search Ψ: si(k+1)←Ψ(s′i(k)),1≤i≤n;
Step 4. Execute the optimization of S(k+1) based on the chaotic disturbance.
4.1. Choose fix(μ×n) individuals with smaller fitness values from S(k+1) to form the population S′(k+1)={s1(k+1),s2(k+1),⋯,sl(k+1)}, where, l=fix(μ×n), 0<μ<1;

4.2. Find the current optimal solution s*(k+1)=a1*(k+1)a2*(k+1)⋯am*(k+1)} from S(k+1), and transform it from the binary-coding space to the variable space: ∀1≤i≤m, xi*(k+1)=e−1(ai*(k+1)). x*(k+1)={x1*(k+1),x2*(k+1),⋯,xm*(k+1)};
4.3. Transform x*(k+1) from the variable space to the chaos space: ∀1≤i≤m, βi*(k+1)=Θ(xi*(k+1)). β*(k+1)={β1*(k+1),β2*(k+1),⋯,βm*(k+1)};

4.4. In the same way, the population S′(k+1) is transformed from the binary-coding space to the variable space and then to the chaos space. The chaos population B(k+1) is formed: ∀s′i(k+1)∈S′(k+1), 1≤i≤l and s′i(k+1)=a′i1(k+1)a′i2(k+1)⋯a′im(k+1), x′i(k+1)={x′i1(k+1),x′i2(k+1),⋯,x′im(k+1)}={e−1(a′i1(k+1)),e−1(a′i2(k+1)),⋯,e−1(a′im(k+1))}. βi(k+1)={βi1(k+1),βi2(k+1),⋯,βim(k+1)}={Θ(x′i1(k+1)),Θ(x′i2(k+1)),⋯,Θ(x′im(k+1))}. B(k+1)={β1,β2,⋯,βl}.
4.5. Execute the chaotic disturbance on B(k+1) according to equations (13), (14) and (15) to achieve the new chaos population B′(k+1);

4.6. Re-transform the B′(k+1) from the chaos space to the variable space and then to the binary-coding space to form the new population S′(k+1): ∀β’i(k+1)∈B′(k+1),1≤i≤l and β’i(k+1)={β′i1(k+1),β′i2(k+1),⋯,β′im(k+1)}, x′ij(k+1)=Θ−1(β′ij(k+1)),1≤j≤m. a′ij(k+1)=e(x′ij(k+1)). s′i(k+1)={a′i1(k+1),a′i2(k+1),⋯,a′im(k+1)}. S′(k+1)={s′1(k+1),s′2(k+1),⋯,s′l(k+1)}.
4.7. Generate the new population: S(k+1)=S′(k+1)∪{sl+1(k),sl+2(k),⋯,sn(k)}.
Step 5. Assess whether the termination condition is met. If not, proceed with the following process, otherwise output the optimal solution and end.

sec.p: The termination condition in the CSWA is the same as the condition mentioned in the pseudo-code of the SSWA.

list-item.p: Step 6. Update the population based on the information entropy.
Step 7. k←k+1, and go to Step 3.

sec.title: Function optimization
sec.p: To verify the optimization capability of the CSWA, six different types of functions were considered, as shown in equations (19) to (24), and selected tests were implemented on an Intel Pentium IV 2.99 GHz computer with 512 MB RAM using the MATLAB language. In recent years, a large number of intelligent optimization algorithms have appeared and have been applied successfully to a variety of engineering fields; these algorithms include the bees algorithm (BA),16 the particle swarm optimization algorithm (PSOA)17 and the GA.18 However, the BA and the PSOA are mainly coded in terms of real numbers and are not suitable for continuous optimization problems. Considering that the GA is characterized by a strong global search capability and is widely used, a modified GA (MGA) 1,19 taken from the Genetic Algorithm Toolbox provided by Chipperfield et al.19 is used in this paper. The test results of the CSWA are compared with those of the SSWA and the MGA.

list-item.p: Rosenbrock function
Schaffer’s f6 function
Needle-in-a-haystack function
Griewank function
Goldstein–Price function
Ackley’s path function

sec.p: In this paper, to address the randomness of intelligent algorithms, each function was independently tested with 50 repetitions. In the CSWA, n = 20, l = 1, pc = 0.8, σ = 10−5, ϑ = 0.9, χ = 0.07, υ = 300, λ = 30, µ = 0.6 and kmax = 1500. In the SSWA, n = 20, l = 1, pc = 0.8 and kmax = 1500. In the MGA, the population size was 20, the crossover probability was 0.7 and the mutation probability was 0.02.

Table 1 shows the performance comparison of the function optimization of the three algorithms. Nbest denotes the number of times an optimal solution was found. Nmax and Nmean denote the maximum and average convergence generations needed to find the optimal solutions, respectively. Nstd denotes the standard deviation of the convergence generation. The table shows that for all functions, except for the Rosenbrock function f1, the SSWA is always able to find the optimal solutions in all tests, and the performances of Nmax, Nmean and Nstd are better than that of the MGA, which shows that the SSWA has a strong search capability. However, for the pathological Rosenbrock function, the SSWA focuses so much on the local search that its optimization result is worse than that of the MGA. In this paper, because the replacement strategies for an individual with higher concentration and chaotic disturbance are used to improve the optimization performance of the SSWA, the CSWA is able to find all optimal solutions of the six complex functions in all tests, which demonstrates its strong search capability. From the Nmax and Nmean, it can be noted that the CSWA has a quicker convergence speed. The performance of Nstd shows the excellent stability of the CSWA.

caption.p: Performance comparisons among the MGA, SSWA and CSWA.

fn.p: MGA: modified genetic algorithm; SSWA: simple small-world algorithm; CSWA: chaotic small-world algorithm.

sec.p: Figure 4 shows one of the optimal solutions distributed in the function space for Schaffer’s f6 function of the CSWA, where “*” denotes the final solutions. From this figure, it can be observed that the CSWA finds the optimal solutions. At the same time, the CSWA also finds the local optimal solutions, which reflects the solution diversity of the CSWA.

caption.p: Optimized results for Schaffer’s f6 function of the CSWA.

sec.p: Figure 5 presents the average evolutionary curves of the optimal solution and the entire population of Schaffer’s f6 function. The function was tested for 50 repetitions, and each test lasted for 500 generations. The figure shows that the average search capability and the convergence speed of the SSWA and the CSWA are clearly better than those of the MGA, and the optimization performance of the CSWA is superior to that of the other algorithms.

caption.p: Average evolutionary curves of Schaffer’s f6 function (a) optimal solution and (b) whole population.
MGA: modified genetic algorithm; SSWA: simple small-world algorithm; CSWA: chaotic small-world algorithm.

sec.title: Parameter experiments for CSWA
sec.p: The test results in Table 1 show that the CSWA is characterized by a strong optimization capability and quick convergence speed. However, for the same function, different algorithm parameters will produce different optimization results. To improve the optimization performance of the CSWA, it is important to perform a study on the algorithm parameters. In this paper, the key parameters of the CSWA, e.g. the long-range search probability pc and threshold value ϑ of similarity, are studied in detail from the viewpoints of the average convergence generation and standard deviation.

sec.title: Selection of long-range search probability pc
sec.p: In the CSWA, the main operation of the random long-range search operator Г is realized through the inversion operation of the node. The probability pc corresponds to the inversion probability of the inversion operation in the evolutionary algorithm, except that a limit is set for the distance between the inversion positions. The operator Г is favorable for generating new schema for the nodes, which will enable the CSWA to retain the population diversity and break away from the local minima. The selection of pc is critical for the random long-range search.

For the above six functions, with all the other algorithm parameters being held constant (namely, n = 20, l = 1, σ = 10−5, ϑ= 0.9, χ = 0.07, υ = 300, λ = 30 and µ = 0.6), function tests were conducted for 50 repetitions executed independently with the increase of pc in [0, 1]. The convergence generation and the standard deviation were normalized. From the average convergence generation (see Figure 6(a)), it can be observed that for the Schaffer’s f6 and Griewank functions (which have many local minimum points), the optimization capability of the CSWA is significantly influenced by pc because the random long-range search of the CSWA is directly affected by the magnitude of pc. With a decrease in pc, the random long-range search effect of the CSWA becomes less and less obvious, and it is difficult for the CSWA to break away from the local minima. When pc = 0, the CSWA is in a state of pure local search, the algorithm is the most unstable, and the convergence speed is the slowest. For other functions that are unimodal or have many global optimal points, pc has little effect on the optimization capability of the CSWA because the local shortcut search and chaotic disturbance of the CSWA can cope with the optimization of those functions. From the standard deviation (see Figure 6(b)), it can be observed that the stability of the CSWA is influenced significantly by pc during the optimization of the Schaffer’s f6 and Griewank functions.

caption.p: Experimental results on the long-range search probability pc (a) average convergence generation and (b) standard deviation.

sec.p: In contrast with the experimental results for pc, it can be seen that the selection of pc should be moderate. If pc is too small, the convergence generation is increased, and the algorithm tends to be unstable. If pc is too large, the instability of the search will occur again. The experimental results indicate that the optimization performance of the CSWA is superior when pc is approximately 0.8.

sec.title: Selection of threshold value ϑ of similarity
sec.p: To improve upon the stagnancy of the SSWA, a replacement strategy for individuals with a high concentration is adopted in this paper to retain the population diversity. The threshold value ϑ of similarity is a critical parameter during the calculation of the individual concentrations. The magnitude of ϑ directly affects the similarity among the individuals and further affects the individual concentrations.

Similar to the selection of pc, and considering the above six functions under the condition that all the other algorithm parameters remain constant (namely, n = 20, l = 1, pc = 0.8, σ = 10−5, χ = 0.07, υ = 300, λ = 30, µ = 0.6), the function was tested by independent execution of 50 repetitions with an increase of pc in [0, 1], and the changes in the average convergence generation and standard deviation were observed. Figure 7 displays the experimental results for ϑ. From the average convergence generation (see Figure 7(a)), it can be observed that for the needle-in-a-haystack and Griewank functions, which have several local minima, the convergence property of the CSWA is influenced significantly by ϑ because an improper ϑ affects the population diversity. However, for Schaffer’s f6 function, whose local minima are around the global optimal point, the random long-range search and chaotic disturbance reduce the effect of ϑ. For the other functions, ϑ has little effect on the optimization capability of the CSWA. From the standard deviation (see Figure 7(b)), it can be observed that for the needle-in-a-haystack and Griewank functions, the stability of the CSWA is influenced significantly by ϑ as well.

caption.p: Experimental results on the threshold value ϑ of similarity (a) average convergence generation and (b) standard deviation.

sec.p: It can be noted from the experimental results for ϑ that the threshold value of ϑ should be moderate in value. If ϑ is too large the individual concentration is decreased, the probability of replacing individuals is reduced, the proposed algorithm is easily trapped in local minima and the convergence generation is increased. However, if ϑ is too small, the individual concentration is increased, and the population diversity is more favorable, but the algorithm is easily trapped in the random state, the convergence generation is increased and the algorithm tends to be unstable. The experimental results indicate that the optimization performance of the CSWA is superior when ϑ is approximately 0.9.

sec.title: Selection of other parameters
sec.p: Selected functional tests were executed in a similar manner for the other parameters of the CSWA (including n, χ and λ). The experimental results indicated that the optimization capability of the CSWA is superior when n is 20, σ is 10−5, χ is 0.07, υ is 3 00, µ is 0.6 and λ is 30.

The problem of how to obtain better algorithm parameters for the CSWA and apply them to different applications is critical but is also difficult to solve. From the existing research results on the algorithm parameters, the simulation approach is taken as the main solution method. In this paper, certain key parameters of the CSWA are tested using six representative functions. The test results for these algorithm parameters based on the set of benchmark problems may not be optimal, but they should be appropriate for extension to other problems, particularly engineering problems. Generally speaking, the complexity of engineering optimization is usually lower than that of complex functions.

sec.title: Path planning based on the CSWA
Free space model based on the MAKLINK graph method
sec.p: Global path planning is an important problem in autonomous mobile robot navigation. Before the path planning can take place, the free space model of the robot must be established. The MAKLINK graph method is one of the better methods for this function.20,21 The following assumptions are made to simplify the problem of establishing the planning space.

list-item.p: The robot moves in a limited 2D workspace, and the heights of the environment and obstacles are ignored.
Certain known static obstacles exist and are distributed throughout the environment, and the environment and obstacles are of polygonal shape.

To deter the robot from moving into close proximity to the obstacles, the boundaries of the obstacles are expanded to a certain extent based on the cross-section of the robot and the required minimum distance between the robot and obstacle; a mass point represents the robot.

sec.p: The MAKLINK graph method can be described simply as follows.

list-item.p: Step 1. Construct the free space within the robot environment in terms of a free convex area using the free link approach.
Step 2. Take the midpoint of each free link as a possible path point.
Step 3. Connect all possible path points within the free convex area.
Step 4. Add starting point “S” and goal point “G”, and connect them with the possible path points within the free convex area.

sec.p: Figure 8 illustrates the working environment for a mobile robot. An area of 10×10m2 is enclosed between the given starting point S and the goal G, and black polygons denote the obstacles.

caption.p: The working environment of the mobile robot.

sec.p: The MAKLINK graph of the working environment for a mobile robot is shown in Figure 9. The white margin denotes the expanded boundaries of the obstacle.

caption.p: MAKLINK graph of the working environment.

sec.p: After the free space model is established using the MAKLINK graph method, the path planning for the mobile robot is transformed into a search for the shortest path in the MAKLINK graph. The search can be solved using many mature algorithms, including the Ford algorithm, the Dijkstra algorithm and others. However, the optimized path is a sub-optimal path because it passes only through the middle points of the free MAKLINK lines. Because the obstacles are expanded, and a mass point in the MAKLINK graph denotes the robot, the robot is able to move along the boundaries of the obstacles. Accordingly, in this paper, the Ford algorithm is used to first generate the sub-optimal path, and then all path points are adjusted again to generate an optimal path using the proposed CSWA.

sec.title: Coding method
sec.p: Assume that the sub-optimal path generated by the Ford algorithm is denoted in order by the path nodes p0, p1, p2, …, pn and pn+1, as shown in Figure 10, where p0 = S is the starting point, and pn+1 = G is the goal point. At the beginning, the path nodes are located in the middle of the free MAKLINK lines. To achieve the optimal path, each path node pi (i =1, 2,…n) must be adjusted.

caption.p: Coding method of the path.

sec.p: Figure 10 shows that path node pi can change along the MAKLINK line pi1pi2, and its location can be expressed as17
where ti is an adjustment coefficient, ∀i∈[1,2,⋯,n], ti∈[0,1].

When all path nodes are treated in the same way, the path can be expressed by a set of values {t1, t2,.., tn}, together with the starting point S and goal G. To facilitate the optimization based on the CSWA, the zero-one binary encoding is adopted.

sec.title: Objective function
sec.p: In this paper, the length of the planned path is taken as the objective function and is defined as follows

sec.title: Planning simulations
sec.p: To verify the effectiveness of the proposed CSWA in path planning and considering the two different environments, shown in Figure 11 and Figure 12, selected simulations were performed using MATLAB 7.0 on an Intel Pentium IV 2.99 GHz computer with 512 MB RAM. The planning results are compared with those of the Ford algorithm, the MGA and the SSWA. To address the randomness, each intelligent algorithm in each environment was independently tested for 50 repetitions. Because it is impossible to know the length of the global optimal path in the two environments in advance, the termination condition of the MGA, SSWA and MGA for path planning is stated as: the specified kmax is reached.

caption.p: Planning results in environment I.
CSWA: chaotic small-world algorithm.
Planning results in environment II.
CSWA: chaotic small-world algorithm.

sec.p: Figures 11 and 12 show the planning results in the considered two environments. From the figures, it can be observed that the paths based on the Ford algorithm are sub-optimal paths, and the paths adjusted by the CSWA are the global optimal paths.

Table 2 allows comparisons among the four algorithms. From the length of the optimal path found in the 50 experiments, the three intelligent algorithms (i.e. MGA, SSWA and CSWA) are able to converge to the optimal path, and the lengths of these paths are shorter than that of the Ford algorithm, which reflects the advantages of the intelligent optimization algorithms in path planning. The average length of all paths found in the 50 experiments demonstrates that the optimization results from the three intelligent algorithms are in close agreement, and the results of the CSWA are superior to those of the other algorithms.

caption.p: Comparisons of the four algorithms.

fn.p: MGA: modified genetic algorithm; SSWA: simple small-world algorithm; CSWA: chaotic small-world algorithm.

sec.p: Figures 13 and 14 illustrate the average evolutionary curves of the three intelligent algorithms (i.e. MGA, SSWA and CSWA) in environments I and II, respectively. Regardless of whether the average evolutionary curves are for all optimal paths or for the entire population, the results show that the average optimization capabilities of the SSWA and the CSWA are better than that of the MGA, and the optimization capability of the CSWA is superior to those of the other algorithms.

caption.p: Average evolutionary curves in environment I (a) all optimal paths and (b) entire population.
MGA: modified genetic algorithm; SSWA: simple small-world algorithm; CSWA: chaotic small-world algorithm.
Average evolutionary curves in environment II (a) all optimal paths and (b) entire population.
MGA: modified genetic algorithm; SSWA: simple small-world algorithm; CSWA: chaotic small-world algorithm.

sec.title: Experimental environment
sec.p: To further verify the validity of the path planning based on the CSWA and the MAKLINK graph, an experiment was carried out in a known environment. Figure 15 shows the experimental environment and experimental system, composed of a wireless sensor network (WSN) based on Zigbee technology, a two-wheeled differential-drive tracked robot with a stepper motor and four obstacles. The WSN system involved a host computer, a location dongle connected to the host computer through an RS232 serial port, eight reference nodes and a blind node (CC2431 Zigbee module) installed on the robot. The CC2431 module provided the wireless location and wireless communications for the robot. The electric compass module and the speed measurement module in the robot were used to calculate the trajectory of the robot via the well-known dead reckoning (DR) method. During the experiment, the robot communicated with the WSN system and received the control instructions from the host computer through the blind node, and the robot performed self-location through the WSN system / DR.

caption.p: Experimental environment for path planning.

sec.p: In Figure 15, the area enclosed by the insulator tape designates the known working environment for the tracked robot. There are four obstacles located in the working environment. Based on the Zigbee WSN system and DR, the robot attempts to complete the navigation from the top left corner to the lower right corner according to the planned path. The path to be followed was planned in the host computer.

sec.title: Experimental results
sec.p: Figure 16 shows the planning results obtained from the experiment. Figure 16(a) shows the starting point of the robot, and Figure 16(b) shows that the robot has adjusted its direction. Figure 16(c) and (d) show that the robot has moved in accordance with the planned optimal path and has avoided obstacle 1. Figure 16(e) shows that the robot has adjusted its direction again. Next, the robot moves as shown in Figure 16(f) to (h). Figure 16(i) shows the third directional adjustment of the robot. Figure 16(j) and (k) show that the robot has avoided obstacles 2 and 3. Figure 16(l) shows the last directional adjustment. Figure 16(m) to (o) show that the robot moved toward and successfully reached the goal. Comparing the actual tracking of the robot with the planned optimal path, it can be observed that there are differences between them that are caused by location error. To improve the planning precision, a vision system will be adopted in the next study.

caption.p: Experimental result of path planning based on the CSWA.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: To avoid trapping in local minima and to improve the optimization capability of the SSWA, a novel SWA incorporating chaos optimization is proposed, and the CSWA is successfully applied to the global path planning of a mobile robot. The following conclusions can be drawn from the theoretical analysis, simulation studies and experimental results.

list-item.p: Using the characteristics of ergodicity, randomicity and regularity of chaotic variables, the initial population of the optimization algorithm is generated by logistic mapping, which ensures better schema for the initial population. The chaos disturbance ameliorates the weak local search capability of the SSWA and improves the local search efficiency of the SSWA.

The individual concentration and fitness are taken as the evaluation criterion, and new individuals replace the individuals with high concentrations, this retains the population diversity and avoids the problem of trapping in local minima.

Compared with related optimization algorithms (including the GA, PSOA and SSWA), the CSWA not only contains the capabilities of parallel computing and global optimization but also demonstrates a strong local optimization for the chaos iteration and local shortcuts connection and is not easily trapped into local minima for the replacement strategy and random long-range connections. The weakness of the CSWA is mainly reflected in the relatively large computation time required for the chaos iteration. The CSWA is suitable for the optimization of multi-variable and multi-constrained systems.

Based on the free space model established with the MAKLINK graph method, a sub-optimal path is first generated using the Ford algorithm, and then the CSWA is used to optimize the final global path. The simulation and experimental results prove that the CSWA is a feasible method for robot path planning.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: f* global optimum of model f
f(x) objective function
kmax maximal evolutionary generation
n size of node population
pc long-rang search probability
s transition node in a m-dimensional small-world network (i.e. individual in the optimization algorithm)
s*(k) optimal individual of the kth generation population
S transition node set in a m-dimensional small-world network (i.e. population in the optimization algorithm)
x variable vector
Г random long-range search operator
ε solution precision
ϑ threshold value of the similarity
λ total iterative generations of chaos disturbance
σ coding precision of variable x
υ total recursive generations of logistic equation
χ threshold value of the concentration
Ψ local shortcuts search operator
